results.title: The Life of birds. Eps 7-10
results.creator_credit: Fergus Beeley, Mike Salisbury and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: The Life of birds, another nature series from the inimitable Attenborough, uncovers new research into the behaviour of birds, secrets of their success, strategies for finding food, complex social systems, and extraordinary ways of breeding and mating. Episodes 7-10 “Finding partners”: Features the bizarre and beautiful copulating rituals of birds, whilst examining the processes of attracting and keeping a mate. “The Demands of the egg”: As birds lay outside their body, the survival of the young depends on the parents’ protection of the precious eggs. Also covers the subject of creating a nest. “The problems of parenthood”: Raising a baby requires the adult bird to utilise a variety of skills to satiate voracious appetites. “The Limits of endurance”: In a constantly changing world, birds must repeatedly alter their patterns to survive nature, man and evolution. This series combines cinematography shot in nature with slow motion and computer-enhanced special effects that allows viewers to observe bird behaviour on a minute level. Attenborough and his crew visited 42 countries to create this magnificent series.

results.title: The Life of birds. Eps 4-6
results.creator_credit: Fergus Beeley, Mike Salisbury and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: The Life of birds, another nature series from the inimitable Attenborough, uncovers new research into the behaviour of birds, secrets of their success, strategies for finding food, complex social systems, and bizarre ways of breeding and mating. Episodes 4-6 “Meat-eaters”: Many birds are carnivores, eating live and dead flesh to survive. In this episode Attenborough explores birds’ competition for hard-to-find prey as the audience observes the various strategies employed by hunter and scavenger birds to source food. “Fishing for a living”: Displays the skilful fishing practices utilised by a variety of birds, across freshwater and saltwater locations. “Signals and songs”: Birdcalls and extraordinary patterns of colour are used for various reasons in the animal kingdom - to communicate, copulate, deter predators and scare off rivals. Attenborough examines a broad range of bird songs and plumage. The series combines cinematography shot in nature with slow motion and computer-enhanced special effects that allows viewers to observe bird behaviour on a minute level. Attenborough and his crew visited 42 countries to create this magnificent series.

results.title: The Life of birds. Eps 1-3
results.creator_credit: Fergus Beeley, Mike Salisbury and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: The Life of birds, another nature series from the inimitable Attenborough, uncovers new research into the behaviour of birds, secrets of their success, strategies for finding food, complex social systems, and bizarre ways of breeding and mating. Episodes 1-3 “To fly or not to fly”: Examines the daily routine of birds in thorough detail, investigating the post-dinosaur phenomenon of birds that walk the earth. “The Mastery of flight”: Celebrates birds’ awesome ability to take to the skies, conveying the majestic speed, endurance, and agility of many creatures. Attenborough discusses the splendid proficiency of birds to fly with aerodynamic skill and grace. Flapping, gliding, thermals, and breathtaking displays of synchronised formation flying are some topics covered. “The Insatiable appetite”: Investigates bird nutrition and food intake. Birds depend on a great variety of food supply, from acorns to zebra meat. Bill shapes and sizes have evolved over time to assure maximum efficiency when sourcing food. The series combines cinematography shot in nature with slow-motion and computer-enhanced special effects that allows viewers to observe bird behaviour on a minute level. Attenborough and his crew visited 42 countries to create this magnificent series.

results.title: The Life history of the onion
results.brief_description: A study of the onion plant: its structure, the various varieties of onions, and how they are cultivated; together with detailed study of the lifecycle of this plant. (Treatment is similar to that of “The Lifecycle of pinmould” 006178).

results.title: The Life cycle of the pin mould
results.creator_credit: Mary Field, Gaumont-British Instructional and British Council
results.brief_description: A study of pin mould, one of the commonest of moulds, often appearing on such food as apples, porridge, bread and other moist substances. Time-lapse and microcinematography show a single spore, the germination of many spores, the spreading from this single spore of a branching mass of mould, and the appearance of heads, which contain new spores, released as the heads ripen. Photographed by Percy Smith.

results.title: The Life cycle of the newt
results.brief_description: A study of the smooth newt, tracing its development from and an egg, through to the tadpole stage, to a fully developed 3 year old newt returning to the pond in spring to breed. The male and female of this species of newt differ in size and colouring. Crested newts, axololts, and salamanders all have a similar cycle.

results.title: The Life cycle of the malaria parasite
results.creator_credit: Charles Legg, Oswald Skilbeck, ICI (GB) and Film Producers Guild
results.brief_description: Explains how the female mosquito bite a human being and infects them with the malaria parasite. Shows how it lodges in the liver and develops. Explains the two types of ‘tertian’ and ‘qurtan’ fevers. Very technical terms are used to explain the redevelopment of the parasites within the mosquito and the many forms of the parasite Presents in animation exoerythrocytic and erythrocytic schizogony and gametogony in man, and sporogony in the Anopheles mosquito; pictures the differential characteristic of plasmodia in thin and thick blood films.

results.title: The Life cycle of the Hercules moth
results.brief_description: Follows the metamorphism from egg to caterpiller to moth. Found in North Queensland and Papua New Guinea the Hercules Moth (Coscinoscera Hercules) is the worlds largest.

results.title: The Life cycle of maize
results.brief_description: A study of maize, the universal corn, from seed to harvest. Time-lapse and microcinematography combine to give a detailed analysis of this plant; the process of germination, and the action of the stomata in fine and wet weather are demonstrated. Experiments demonstrate which minerals are necessary in the soil if maize is to grow successfully.
